questions.text: 1. Which of the following represents the first germ layer to be formed and the cells it originates from?
questions.solution:
The first germ layer to be formed is the endoderm, and it originates from epiblasts.

Epiblasts give rise to all three germ layers through the process of gastrulation.

After the formation of the primitive streak, the epiblast cells migrate towards the primitive streak. When they arrive at the primitive streak, these cells become flask-shaped, detach from the epiblast, and slip beneath the primitive streak. This inward movement is known as invagination.

Some of the invaginated epiblast cells displace the hypoblast to create the embryonic endoderm. Endoderm is the first germ layer to form. Some of the invaginated cells then start occupying the space between the epiblast and newly created endoderm to form mesoderm. Cells remaining in the epiblast then form the ectoderm.

questions.text: 2. The vessel marked in the image below ascends upwards over the right hemithorax and ultimately drains into the superior vena cava. It originates from all the given vessels except?
questions.solution:
The marked image represents the azygos system of veins. The right brachiocephalic vein does not contribute to its origin. 

The azygos system of veins drains the thoracic wall and the upper lumbar region. It is formed by the union of the lumbar azygos, right subcostal, and right ascending lumbar veins. The lumbar azygos vein is considered the abdominal part of the azygos vein and its lower end communicates with the IVC.

It enters the thorax by passing through the aortic opening in the diaphragm. It ascends to the level of the 4th thoracic vertebra, arching forward over the root of the right lung, and ends by joining the posterior aspect of the superior vena cava before piercing the pericardium.

It occupies the upper part of the posterior abdominal wall and the posterior mediastinum. It forms a connecting channel between the superior and inferior venae cavae. It also connects the portal, caval system, and vertebral venous systems.

Tributaries of the azygous system of veins:

* Right superior intercostal vein - formed by the union of the 2nd, 3rd, and 4th posterior intercostal veins

* 5-11th right posterior intercostal veins

* Hemi-azygos vein at the level of the lower border of the 8th thoracic vertebra

* Accessory hemiazygos vein at the level of the upper border of the 8th thoracic vertebra

* Right bronchial vein near the terminal end of the azygos vein

* Several oesophageal, mediastinal, and pericardial veins

The hemi-azygos vein is formed by the union of the left lumbar azygos, left ascending lumbar, and left subcostal veins.

The 9th to 11th left posterior intercostal veins and esophageal veins drain into the hemi-azygous vein. It is also known as the inferior hemi-azygos vein.

The accessory hemiazygos vein is also known as the superior hemiazygos vein. 5th to 8th left posterior intercostal veins and sometimes the left bronchial veins drain into the accessory hemiazygos vein.

questions.text: 3. Which of the following statements is false regarding the wall of the veins?

choices.text: It is thinner than that of the arteries
The tunica adventitia is thicker than the tunica media
The tunica media contains a lesser quantity of collagen than in arteries
The amount of elastic tissue and smooth muscle is much less than arteries

questions.solution:
Option C is false: The tunica media of the veins contains larger quantities of collagen than that of arteries.

questions.text: 4. Identify the structure marked as B in the given image.
questions.solution:
The structure marked as B in the given image is­­ Gimbernat's (lacunar) ligament.

Lacunar ligament is a thick triangular band of tissue formed from fibers of the medial end of the inguinal ligament and fascia lata, lying posterior to it.  It forms the medial wall of the femoral canal. The apex of the triangle is attached to the pubic tubercle.

Other options:

Options A and C: Inguinal (Poupart’s) ligament- The thick external oblique aponeurosis stretched between the anterior superior iliac spine and pubic tubercle.

Option D: Pectineal (Coopers) ligament- A strong fibrous band that extends laterally along the pectineal line from the pectineal attachment of lacunar ligament.

questions.text: 5. A cardiac surgeon demonstrates the following recess to his juniors and explains that it allows the surgeons to isolate and apply a temporary aortic cross-clamping. The sinus he is referring to lies anterior to the ____.

choices.text: Superior venacava and left atrial appendage

questions.solution:
The sinus pointed out is the transverse sinus. 

The reflections of the serous pericardium are arranged as two tubes – one enclosing the aorta and the pulmonary trunk and the other enclosing the vena cavae and the four pulmonary veins. 

The transverse sinus is a passage between the two 'tubes'. It lies superior to the left atrium. It lies posterior to the aorta and the pulmonary trunk and anterior to the superior vena cava and the left atrial appendage. Inferiorly it is related to the oblique sinus.

The zone of reflection surrounding the veins is J-shaped and the cul-de-sac formed within the J is the oblique pericardial sinus. This lies posterior to the left atrium

The image below shows the posterior view of the heart demonstrating the oblique and the transverse sinus.



Clinical significance:

During cardiac surgery, the transverse pericardial sinus allows a surgeon to isolate the pulmonary trunk and ascending aorta and apply a temporary ligature or clamp.

questions.text: 6. Sinus which is not present in falx cerebri is ___________
questions.solution:
Falx cerebri does not contain occipital sinus.

The falx cerebri is a sickle-shaped dural fold separating the right and left cerebral hemispheres. It contains the superior sagittal, inferior sagittal, and straight sinuses in it.

Occipital sinus is present in Falx cerebelli. Falx cerebelli separates the cerebellar hemispheres.

Sigmoid sinus continuous with the internal jugular vein

questions.text: 7. A patient undergoes laparoscopic surgery for an internal hernia near the duodenojejunal flexure. During surgery, the surgeon finds the herniated bowel loop behind a fold of peritoneum containing the inferior mesenteric vein. What is the site of the herniation?
questions.solution:
This herniation is most likely through the paraduodenal recess (Fossa of Landzert).

Paraduodenal hernia most commonly occurs through the paraduodenal recess near the duodenojejunal flexure. It is bounded in front by the para duodenal fold with a right free margin which contains the inferior mesenteric vein and an ascending branch of the left colic.

Superior and inferior duodenal recesses (Options A and B) are smaller and rarely cause hernias.

Comparison of Duodenal Recesses and Clinical Significance:

Recess

Location

Clinical Significance

Superior Duodenal Recess

At the duodenojejunal flexure, above it

Rare site of internal hernia

Inferior Duodenal Recess

At the duodenojejunal flexure, below it

Rare site of inferior duodenal hernia

Paraduodenal Recess

To the left of the duodenojejunal flexure

Common site of paraduodenal hernia. Related to inferior mesenteric vein and ascending branch of left colic artery in its fold (may damage IMV during surgery)

Mesenterico-Parietal Recess

Behind the root of the mesentery, near the ascending duodenum

Mesenterico-parietal hernia, causes intestinal obstruction

questions.text:
8. Which of the following muscles form the structure marked as "X" in the image?

* First lumbrical

* First palmar interossei

* Second palmar interossei

* First dorsal interossei

* Second dorsal interossei
questions.solution:
The structure marked as "X" in the given image is the dorsal digital expansion (extensor expansion) of the index finger. It is formed by the 1st lumbrical, 1st dorsal interossei and 2nd palmar interossei, the extensor digitorum slip and extensor indicis.

Dorsal digital expansion/ Extensor expansion: It is a small triangular aponeurosis covering the dorsum of the proximal phalanx. It is formed by the expansion of extensor tendons (digital expansion). It is located in the back of the digits (dorsal). The extensors making the expansion are the extensor digitorum and extensor pollicis longus. The muscles joining the expansion are extensor digiti minimi, extensor indicis, and extensor pollicis brevis.

Extensor expansion triangular hood attachments: (The shape of expansion)    The apex is attached to the distal phalanx. The central region is attached to the middle phalanx (in the thumb, attached to the proximal phalanx). The corner of the base is attached to the sides of the metacarpophalangeal joint (in the thumb, attached to muscles). The extensor hood is attached to the lumbricals, interossei, and extensor digitorum muscles (in the thumb, the adductor pollicis, and the abductor pollicis brevis muscles).

Wing tendons refer to the insertion of lumbricals and interossei to the corners of the dorsal digital expansion or simply extensor expansion.



The extensor expansion trifurcates into a central slip and two lateral slips which are inserted on the dorsum of the base of the middle phalanx and the dorsum of the base of the distal phalanx.

Extensor expansion

  • Second palmar interosseous
  • First lumbrical
  • Extensor digitorum slip
  • Extensor indicis

Note: As per convention, the lumbricals and interossei are numbered from the lateral to medial side of the palm. The first palmar interosseous muscle, also known as the pollical palmar interosseous muscle may be occassionally rudimentary/absent. As per anatomical nomenclature, the palmar interosseous of the index is referred to as the second palmar interosseous muscle regardless of the presence or absence of the pollical palmar interossei.

questions.text:
10. Assertion - The Heel prick test in newborns should be performed in the area shaded yellow.
Reason - Heel prick site is designated to avoid injury to the underlying neurovascular structures.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is false but the reason is true
Both assertion and reason are true but the reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is true but the reason is false

questions.solution:
The assertion is false. The medial and lateral aspects of the heel (shaded blue) are the preferred safe sites for the heel prick capillary blood testing of neonates, as this avoids injury to the nerves and vessels in the region and also to the calcaneum bone itself.



The sensory nerve supply to the sole of the foot is by:

* Medial calcaneal nerve (branch of the tibial nerve) - innervates the medial side of the heel.

* Medial plantar nerve - innervates the medial two-thirds of the sole.

* Lateral plantar nerve - innervates the lateral third of the sole.

questions.text: 11. A 70-year-old woman with a history of hypertension develops sudden onset ataxia and sensory loss. On examination, there was loss of vibration and proprioception below T6, but the motor function and the pain and temperature sensations were preserved. Which vessel is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of the involvement of the posterior spinal artery.

A posterior column lesion typically affects vibration and proprioception, leaving pain, temperature, and motor function intact. The posterior column is supplied by the posterior spinal artery.

The posterior spinal arteries are paired vessels supplying the posterior one-third of the spinal cord, including dorsal columns and dorsal horns. They arise from the vertebral arteries or posterior inferior cerebellar arteries and ensure proprioception and vibration sense; infarction causes loss of these modalities without motor deficits.

Feature

Anterior Spinal Artery (ASA)

Posterior Spinal Artery (PSA)

Artery of Adamkiewicz

Area supplied

Anterior 2/3 of spinal cord

Posterior 1/3 of spinal cord

Joins ASA; major supply to lower cord (T8–L2)

Key tracts affected

Corticospinal, Spinothalamic

Dorsal columns

Similar to ASA (since it supplies ASA)

Motor loss

Yes (bilateral) – paralysis below lesion

No

Yes (paraplegia)

Pain & Temp loss

Yes (bilateral)

No

Yes

Vibration & Position

Preserved

Lost

Preserved

Yes (bladder, bowel dysfunction)

No

Common cause

Atherosclerosis, aortic surgery, trauma

Rare; infarct or tumor compression

Aortic surgery/aneurysm repair injury

Clinical hallmark

Sudden paraplegia, pain/temp loss, dorsal column spared

Ataxia, loss of position sense

Sudden paraplegia during/after surgery


Other options- 

Option A- Anterior spinal artery (ASA): Supplies anterior 2/3 (corticospinal + spinothalamic) → would cause motor weakness and pain/temperature loss.

Option B- Artery of Adamkiewicz / Great radicular artery: feeds the ASA in lower 2/3rds of the spinal cord → pattern would mimic ASA syndrome, not PSA.

Option C- Posterior radicular artery supplies nerve roots, not major cord tracts.

questions.text: 12. What does Cantlie's line represent?
questions.solution:
Cantlie’s line is another name for the main portal fissure which extends from the midpoint of the gallbladder fossa at the inferior margin of the liver to the midpoint of the inferior vena cava. It divides the liver into the right and left hemiliver. It contains the middle hepatic vein.

Umbilical fissure - It separates segment 3 from segment 4, within the left medial sector. It is marked by the attachment of the falciform ligament.

Venous fissure - It is a direct continuation of the umbilical fissure on the undersurface of the liver. It contains the ligamentum venosum (obliterated ductus venosus).

Fissure of Ganz - It lies on the undersurface of the right lobe of the liver behind the gallbladder fossa. It is also called Rouviere’s sulcus. It marks the division of the portal pedicle to the right posterior sector.



Couinaud's classification divides the liver into 4 sectors based on supply by portal venous branches. These sectors are further divided into 2 segments based on vascular biliary sheath supplying it. It is but however, a functional or physiological classification. For surgery, based on the hepatic veins draining the liver part, it is divided by 3 major portal fissures not visible on the liver surface but present within the liver parenchyma.

* The main portal fissure called Cantlie's line divides the liver into right and left hemi-liver. It contains the middle hepatic vein.

* The left portal fissure divides the left hemi-liver into medial (anterior) and lateral (posterior) segments. It contains the left hepatic vein.

* The right portal fissure divides the right hemi-liver into medial (anterior) and lateral (posterior) segments. It contains the right hepatic vein.

Pearl PM1159: Couinaud's liver segments

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

* Based on the distribution of hepatic portal venous branches in the parenchyma

* Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

Other segments:

Liver sections

Couinaud's Segments

Right anterior sections

Segments V,VIII

Right Posterior sections

Segments VI, VII

Left medial sections

Segment IV (quadrate lobe)

Left lateral sections

Segment II, III

questions.text: 13. A 35-year-old man suffered a severe traumatic injury of the right upper limb for which he underwent a surgical ligation of the proximal part of the axillary artery to control the bleeding. The upper limb still received blood supply through collateral circulation around the scapula. Which artery does not contribute to this collateral circulation?
questions.solution:
The anterior circumflex humeral artery does not participate in scapular anastomosis.

Scapular anastomosis provides collateral circulation when the axillary artery is ligated proximal to the subscapular artery. The key contributors are:

* Suprascapular artery (thyrocervical trunk)

* Circumflex scapular artery (branch of subscapular artery)

* Dorsal scapular artery (branch of transverse cervical artery or subclavian)

The anterior circumflex humeral artery is a branch of the third part of the axillary artery. It gives rise to the ascending branch which contributes to the anastomosis around the shoulder joint.

questions.text: 14. All of the following structures form the floor of the 4th ventricle, except _____.
questions.solution:
All of the listed structures form the floor of the 4th ventricle, except superior and inferior medullary velum, which form the roof of the 4th ventricle.

Structures on the floor of the 4th ventricle (Rhomboid Fossa)

Ridges:

* Transverse fibers: Striae medullares

* Striae medullares divides rhomboid fossa into 2 parts: Rostral pontine and Caudal medullary 

Medial to lateral in rostral pontine part:

* Midline longitudinal sulcus: Median sulcus

* Bilateral eminences: Medial eminence

* Bilateral longitudinal sulcus: Sulcus limitans

* Bilateral areas: Vestibular area (deeper to it is the vestibular nucleus)

Upper and lower ends of sulcus:

* Bluish-colored, uppermost area where sulcus limitans ends: Locus coeruleus

* Depression, the upper area of sulcus limitans: Superior fovea

* Depression, the lower area of sulcus limitans: Inferior fovea

Cranial nerve nucleus elevations:

* Elevation on the medial eminence: Facial colliculus

* Elevations in the lowermost area in the shape of 2 triangles: Hypoglossal and vagal triangles

Circumventricular organ:

* Between the vagal triangle and gracile tubercle below: Area postrema

questions.text: 15. Which of the following structures form the secretomotor pathway for the gland marked as 'X'?

choices.text: Superior salivary nucleus and 7th cranial nerve
Inferior salivary nucleus and 9th cranial nerve
Superior salivary nucleus and 9th cranial nerve
Inferior salivary nucleus and 7th cranial nerve

questions.solution:
The structure marked X is the submandibular gland, and the secretomotor pathway for the gland is from the superior salivary nucleus and 7th cranial nerve.

Secretomotor pathway of salivary glands: Parasympathetic fibers regulate salivary secretion. Secretions of parotid gland are regulated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) and that of submandibular and sublingual glands is mediated by chorda tympani nerves (branch of facial nerve- CN VII).

Functions of the secretomotor pathway include: Stimulate watery, enzyme-rich saliva, aid digestion, oral lubrication, antimicrobial action, buffering pH, and maintaining oral mucosal health.

* Nervus intermedius, also called the nerve of Wrisberg, is the sensory & secretomotor component of the facial nerve.

* The main trunk of the facial nerve, as it exits the brainstem, only carries motor fibers.

questions.text: 16. A 50-year-old man presents with a classic triad of flank pain, left flank mass, and hematuria. A renal biopsy is planned to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following is incorrect with respect to the boundaries of the left kidney?

choices.text: The upper border of morrison's parallelogram passes through T11
The lower border of Morrison's parallelogram passes through L3
The renal angle overlies the upper border of the kidney
The renal angle is bound by the 12th rib and erector spinae

questions.solution:
The renal angle overlies the lower border of the kidney.

The given clinical scenario points towards a likely diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma. A biopsy is done to confirm or refute the diagnosis. Although, blind biopsy has mostly been replaced by a USG/CT guided biopsy. Knowing the relations of the kidney may be helpful in doing a renal biopsy. 

Morrison's parallelogram is marked by 2 horizontal lines passing through T11 and L3. Kidneys lie in this parallelogram when approached from the back, hence, helpful in surface marking for renal biopsy.

The renal angle is bound by the 12th rib and erector spinae and it overlies the lower border of the kidney.

questions.text: 17. What is the location of the cervical flexure in the developing brain?

choices.text: Between the telencephalon and the diencephalon

questions.solution:
Cervical flexure is present between hindbrain (myelencephalon) and spinal cord.

The prosencephalon, mesencephalon, and rhombencephalon are initially arranged craniocaudally. Due to the differential growth of different regions of the brain, various flexures form between them: 

* Telencephalic flexure: Between the telencephalon and the diencephalon.

* Cephalic flexure (mesencephalic flexure): Present in the region of the midbrain (mesencephalon). 

* Pontine flexure: Within the hindbrain; present between the metencephalon and myelencephalon.

* Cervical flexure: Between hindbrain (myelencephalon) and spinal cord.



Note: A deep furrow called the rhombencephalic isthmus separates the mesencephalon from the metencephalon.

questions.text: 18. What is the distance of the area marked by the red arrow from the pylorus of the stomach?
questions.solution:
The marked area corresponds to the opening of the pancreatic and the common bile duct in the second part of the duodenum. This is about 8 to 10 cm from the pylorus of the stomach.

The pancreatic duct and the common bile duct join together to form a common channel. This opens into a mucosal elevation in the posteromedial wall of the second part of the duodenum called the major duodenal papilla. This is about 8 to 10 cm from the pylorus of the stomach.

Knowing the distance of the papilla(the opening of the pancreatic and common bile duct) from the pylorus of the stomach is important in endoscopic procedures. Once the pylorus is visualized, the surgeon needs to advance the scope by 8-10 cm to visualize the papilla and gain access to the biliopancreatic ducts by sphincterotomy.

At times, an accessory pancreatic duct is present which opens into the minor duodenal papilla about 6 to 8cm from the pylorus of the stomach.

questions.text: 19. You are a first-year student who has been asked to identify the hybrid muscle during dissection of the lower limb. You correctly point towards the biceps femoris. What is the nerve supply of this muscle?

choices.text: Tibial part of sciatic nerve, Common fibular nerve
Anterior division of obturator nerve, Tibial part of sciatic nerve
Posterior division of obturator nerve, Femoral nerve

questions.solution:
Biceps femoris is supplied by tibial part of sciatic nerve and common fibular nerve. 

Muscles supplied by two different motor nerves with different root values are called hybrid or composite muscles.

questions.text: 20. Which of the following sites does not represent an anatomical ureteric constriction?
questions.solution:
Crossing of the ureter at the ischial spine is not considered an anatomical constriction of the ureter.

The regions of the ureter which prevent renal calculi from passing freely are the ureteric constrictions. The ureter is constricted at 5 places:

* At the pelvic ureteric junction

* At the brim of the lesser pelvis (as it crosses the common Iliac artery)

* At the site of crossing of the ureter by ductus deferens or broad ligament of the uterus.

* Vesico-ureteric junction

* At its opening in the lateral angle of the trigone

These are regarded as surgical constrictions of the ureter. However, the anatomical constrictions are only three of them (1, 2, and 4).

Clinical note: The constrictions are what prevent renal calculi from passing freely, of these the vesico-ureteric junction is the narrowest and can be responsible for arresting the passage of stones of as little as 2–3 mm.

questions.text: 21. A primigravida at 15 weeks of gestation presents with right lower abdominal pain on waking up in the morning, on rolling over in bed, and vigorous activity. The doctor suspects that the pain is caused by the spasm of the structure marked "A" in the image below. This structure is derived from?
questions.solution:
The structure marked as "A" is the round ligament, which is a derivative of the gubernaculum. 

The given clinical vignette describes round ligament pain, which is caused by spasms or irritation of the round ligament and nerves around the structure. The round ligaments starts near cornua, courses through the inguinal ring, and inguinal canal to end in the labia majora.

Clinical features:

* It is present on the right side of the abdomen/pelvis. Sometimes, this pain might be bilateral

* Commonly presents in early pregnancy and is a diagnosis of exclusion

* Usually after waking up, changing position abruptly, and after strenuous work

* There are no characteristic physical or examination findings

* No treatment is required, and it subsides on its own

questions.text: 22. During dissection, the anatomy professor explains the spaces around the shoulder joint. All of the following statements about the spaces are true, except:

choices.text: Injury to the nerve present in quadrangular space results in difficulty in abduction
Injury to the nerve present in lower triangular space results in wrist drop
The upper triangular space contains circumflex scapular vessels
The quadrangular space of Velpeau is medially bound by short head of triceps

questions.solution:
The quadrangular space of Velpeau is medially bound by the long head of the triceps.

There are 3 spaces around the shoulder joint: triangular space, quadrangular space, and triangular interval.

Triangular space (TS) or upper triangular space:

Boundaries:

* Superiorly: Subscapularis anteriorly, teres minor posteriorly

* Laterally: Long head of triceps

* Inferiorly: Teres major

Contents of the space include circumflex scapular artery(Option C).

Quadrangular space of Velpeau (QS):

Boundaries:

* Anteriorly: Subscapularis

* Superiorly: Capsule of the shoulder joint, teres minor

* Medially: Long head of triceps

* Inferiorly: Teres major

* Laterally: Surgical neck of humerus

Contents of the space include axillary nerve and posterior circumflex humeral vessels. Axillary nerve injury causes difficulty in abduction(Option A).

Triangular interval (TI) or Lower triangular space:

Boundaries:

* Superiorly: Subscapularis anteriorly, teres major posteriorly

* Medially: Long head of triceps

* Laterally: Humerus

Contents of the space include radial nerve and profunda brachii vessels. Radial nerve injury results in wrist drop(Option B).



An easy way to remember these spaces is to represent your 4 fingers as structures around the 3 spaces as shown below.

questions.text: 23. A 55-year-old man is undergoing a CT scan for evaluation of an upper abdominal mass. The radiologist comments that the mass lies at the level of the transpyloric plane. Which of the following structures is not found at this level?
questions.solution:
The origin of the celiac trunk does not lie at the transpyloric plane (L1 vertebral level). It lies at T12 vertebral level.

The transpyloric plane (Addison's plane)passes midway between the suprasternal notch of the manubrium and the upper border of the pubicsymphysis. This approximately corresponds to midway between the xiphisternal joint and the umbilicus. Posteriorly, this plane passes through the lower half of the body of the first lumbar vertebra (lower border of L1). 

Structures present in the transpyloric plane:

Organs 

* Pylorus of stomach D1 part of the duodenum

* Duodenojejunal flexure

* Fundus of the gallbladder

* Hilum of the left kidney (right kidney is slightly lower)

Neurovascular structures

* Origin of the superior mesenteric artery

* Origin of the renal artery

* Origin of the portal vein (behind the neck of the pancreas)

* Lower limit of the spinal cord in adults

* Cisterna chyli

Pearl PM0592: Abdominal planes and their landmarks



Planes that divide the abdomen into 9 regions are:

* Horizontal planes 

* At the level of L3 - Subcostal plane (between 10th costal cartilages). It corresponds to the 3rd part of the duodenum

* At the level of L5 - Transtubercular plane (between tubercles of iliac crests). It corresponds to the origin of inferior vena cava. 

* Vertical planes (paramedian or lateral planes)

* From mid-clavicular point to mid-inguinal point on both sides 

The nine regions of the abdomen include:

* Right hypochondriac, epigastric, left hypochondriac

* Right lumbar, umbilical (central), left lumbar

* Right iliac, hypogastric (suprapubic), left iliac

Other planes and angles in the abdomen are:

* Transpyloric (Addison's) plane - passes midway between the suprasternal notch and the upper border of the pubic symphysis.

* Supracristal plane - passes through the highest point of the iliac crest on both sides. It corresponds to the level of the L4 body or L4/5 disc and its spinous process. It is an important landmark when performing a lumbar puncture or spinal injection. The bifurcation of the abdominal aorta lies approximately in this plane.

* The plane of the pubic crest - passes through the upper border of the pubic symphysis. In supine, this plane intersects the tip of the coccyx and the femoral head.

* Renal angle - between the 12th rib and the outer border of erector spinae muscle. The lower border of normal kidneys may occasionally be felt here. 

* Lumbar triangle of Petit - formed below by the iliac crest, anteriorly by external oblique, and posteriorly by latissimus dorsi. Lumbar hernia can occur here.

questions.text: 24. Identify the correct statement regarding the area marked in the given image.

choices.text: Posterior border is formed by the posterior belly of digastric
Facial artery runs anteriorly with an upward loop
Floor is formed by thyrohyoid and hyoglossus
External jugular vein is the content of the triangle

questions.solution:
The marked area is the carotid triangle, and the floor of the carotid triangle is formed by parts of thyrohyoid, hyoglossus, and inferior and middle pharyngeal constrictor muscles.

Boundaries of carotid triangle:

* Posteriorly it is bounded by sternocleidomastoid.

* Anteroinferiorly by the superior belly of omohyoid.

* Superiorly by stylohyoid and the posterior belly of digastric.

* Roof is formed by skin, superficial fascia, platysma, and deep fascia containing branches of the facial and cutaneous cervical nerves.

* Floor is formed by parts of thyrohyoid, hyoglossus, inferior and middle pharyngeal constrictor muscles.

Contents of carotid triangle:

* Carotid arteries: Common, internal, and external carotid artery

* Branches of the external carotid artery: superior thyroid, lingual (has a characteristic upward loop), facial, ascending pharyngeal, and occipital artery.

* Internal jugular vein

* Vagus nerve

* Hypoglossal nerve

* Spinal part of the accessory nerve

* Superior and inferior roots of ansa cervicalis

questions.text: 25. Which of the following do not contribute to the embryological development of the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The marked structure in the given image is the inferior vena cava (IVC). 

The inferior vena cava is a composite vessel that develops from the remodeling of successive venous complexes. The veins contributing to the formation of IVC from below upwards are as follows:

* Common iliac veins

* Right posterior cardinal vein

* Postcardinal-supracardinal anastomosis

* Right supracardinal vein

* Supracardinal-subcardinal anastomosis

* Right subcardinal vein

* Cardiac termination of the right vitelline hepatocardiac vein (right hepatocardiac vein)

The right umbilical vein atrophies during development. The left umbilical vein joins the right vitelline vein and their common termination is known as the right hepatocardiac vein, which forms the terminal part of the IVC.

questions.text: 26. A 24-year-old man started working out as part of his new year's resolution. He exercised without adequate warm-up and developed thigh pain. MRI revealed a tear of the hamstring muscle with the following origin and insertions. Which muscle is affected?
questions.solution:
The given description of a hamstring muscle with origin on ischial tuberosity and insertion on fibula is the biceps femoris. 

Hamstrings are muscles of the back of the thigh that act as a flexor of the knee and extensors of the hip. While biceps cause lateral rotation of the leg, semimembranosus, and semitendinosus cause medial rotation. They take origin from the ischial tuberosity and are attached to one of the bones of the leg. The short head of biceps femoris takes origin from the lateral lip of linea aspera.

All are innervated by the tibial part of the sciatic nerve except biceps. Biceps is a hybrid muscle, the long head is innervated by the tibial part of sciatic nerve and the short head by the common fibular part of the sciatic nerve.

 

Origin

Insertion

Biceps femoris (long head)

Inferomedial part of the upper area of Ischial tuberosity

Head of the fibula

Semi tendinosus

Inferomedial part of the upper area of Ischial tuberosity

Medial surface of the proximal tibia

Semi membranosus

Superolateral impression on the Ischial tuberosity

Groove and adjacent bone on the medial and posterior surface of medial Tibial condolences.

Adductor Magnus (hamstring part)

Inferolateral part of Ischial tuberosity

Gluteal tuberosity, Linea Aspera, medial supracondylar line, Adductor tubercle.

questions.text:
27. Arrange the following in proper order of blood supply to the uterus.

1 - Arcuate artery 2 - Basal artery 3 - Radial artery 4 - Spiral artery 5 - Uterine artery
questions.solution:
The correct order of the blood supply of the uterus is 5-1-3-2-4

The blood supply of the uterus is as follows:

Uterine artery (5) -> Arcuate artery (1) -> Radial artery (3) -> Basal artery (2) (Supplies basal layer of endometrium ) -> Spiral artery (4) (Supplies functional endometrium)

Bleeding during normal menstruation is due to the rupture of the spiral artery.





The uterine artery is a branch of the anterior trunk of the internal iliac artery.

Branches of the uterine artery:

* Ureteric branch

* Vaginal branches (descending) - these unite to form the anterior and posterior azygos arteries of the vagina

* Circular cervical branch

* Sampson's artery - it runs in under the round ligament. It represents the anastomosis of the uterine artery and ovarian artery.

* Arcuate--> Radial--> Basal--> Spiral and straight arterioles of the functional layer of the endometrium

questions.text: 28. What is the type of joint found in the manubriosternum?
questions.solution:
The Manubriosternal joint is a secondary cartilaginous joint. 

Joints in the thoracic cavity are of the following types:

* Synarthrosis - structures are connected by a fibrous band of tissue. Example: 1st sternocostal joint

* Synchondrosis/primary cartilaginous joints. Example: costochondral joints

* Symphysis/secondary cartilaginous joints. Example: Manubriosternal and xiphisternal joints 

* Synovial joints - the presence of these helps the thoracic cavity expand during inspiration. E.g.:

* Interchondral joint

* Sternocostal joint

* Costovertebral joint

* Costotransverse joint

Secondary cartilaginous joints are characterized by the presence of a fibrocartilaginous disc that connects the articular surfaces, which are covered by a thin layer of hyaline cartilage. These joints are considered permanent. Examples of secondary cartilaginous joints include the symphysis pubis, the manubriosternal joint, and the intervertebral joints between the vertebral bodies.

Synchondrosis refers to the primary cartilaginous joints in which the advancing areas of ossification are separated by hyaline cartilage. They are temporary joints and are associated with growth. Hyaline cartilage has the ability to ossify with age, thus making these joints undergo synostosis once the growth is complete. An example of this type of joint is the epiphyseal plate. 

Synarthrosis - structures are connected by a fibrous band of tissue. E.g, 1st sternocostal joint

Syndesmosis refers to a type of joint where bones are connected by true fibrous tissue. In some cases, this connection is established through an interosseous ligament, as seen in the tibiofibular syndesmosis and radioulnar syndesmosis. In other instances, the connection is formed by a dense fibrous membrane, particularly in the posterior region of the sacroiliac joint.

The given image shows types of joints in the ribcage:

questions.text: 29. Which of the following is a Y-shaped ligament that connects the calcaneum to the cuboid and navicular bone?
questions.solution:
Chopart's ligament is a Y-shaped ligament that connects calcaneum to the cuboid and navicular bone.

It is related to both calcaneocuboid and calcaneonavicular joints. It is a strong Y-shaped band, having a proximal stem and 2 distal limbs.

* The proximal limb is attached by a stem to the anterior part of the upper calcaneal surface.

* The distal limb divides into calcaneocuboid and calcaneonavicular parts.



Other options:

Option A: The Lisfranc ligament connects the medial cuneiform to the base of the 2nd metatarsal. It is a cuneometatarsal interosseous ligament. It is the strongest ligament among the three cuneometatarsal interosseous ligaments. It passes from the lateral surface of the medial cuneiform to the adjacent angle of the second metatarsal bone. 

Deformity of this ligament can lead to instability and deformity of the tarsometatarsal joint.



Option B: Spring ligament, also known as the plantar calcaneonavicular ligament, connects the sustentaculum tali to the navicular. It ties the calcaneus to the navicular and maintains the medial longitudinal arch of the foot. It is made up of the superomedial calcaneonavicular portion and the inferior calcaneonavicular portion.



Option D: Deltoid ligament also called the medial collateral ligament is attached to the apex, anterior and posterior borders of the medial malleolus. It has 2 layers, superficial and deep:

* The superficial layer consists of tibionavicular fibers anteriorly, tibiocalcaneal fibers in the middle, and superficial posterior tibiotalar fibers posteriorly.

* The deep layer consists of anterior tibiotalar fibers, tibiocalcaneal in the middle, and deep posterior tibiotalar posteriorly.

questions.text: 30. A 38-year-old typist presents with pain in the proximal forearm and numbness in the lateral three and a half fingers. On examination, there is tenderness over the proximal forearm. Tinel’s sign is positive. Which anatomical structure is most likely compressing the involved nerve in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of pronator syndrome in which the median nerve is entrapped between the heads of pronator teres muscle.

Pronator syndrome is an entrapment neuropathy involving the median nerve, which occurs in the elbow region. The condition is rare compared to other two compartment syndromes, viz. Carpal tunnel syndrome (compression at wrist) and anterior interosseous syndrome (which occurs due to isolated injury to the anterior interosseous branch of the median nerve).

Sites of entrapment in pronator syndrome:

* Site of ligament of Struthers: This ligament is an anatomical variant, if present connects the supracondylar process of humerus also called avian spur to an accessory origin of pronator teres.

* Deep to bicipital aponeurosis

* Tendinous aponeurotic arch which forms the proximal free edge of the radial attachment of the flexor digitorum superficialis

* Superficial and deep heads of the pronator teres muscle

Clinical features:

* Pain on the volar aspect of the distal arm and proximal forearm

* Paresthesia of the volar forearm and the radial three digits and radial aspect of the fourth digit

* Variable weakness may be present with unspecified grip clumsiness

* The proximal volar forearm is painful to palpation, and Tinel’s sign (Light percussion over the region of nerve to elicit a sensation of tingling or "pins and needles" in the distribution of the nerve.) can be elicited on palpation of the pronator teres muscle.

Aggravation of the symptoms may be seen by the following actions:

* Flexion at elbow against resistance

* Pronation of the forearm against resistance

* Flexion of the superficialis muscle to the middle finger against resistance

Other options- 

Option A- Flexor retinaculum: Flexor retinaculum compression causes carpal tunnel syndrome, producing symptoms at the wrist and hand, not proximal forearm pain.

Option C- Flexor carpi ulnaris muscle belly -Flexor carpi ulnaris is related to ulnar nerve compression at the cubital tunnel, not median nerve.

Option D- Pronator quadratus head → Rare, would involve AIN, leading to inability to flex thumb interphalangeal joint and index distal interphalangeal joint .

questions.text:
31. Given below are the various structures that constitute a lymph node.Which of the following shows the correct sequence for the flow of lymph inside the lymph node?

1: Afferent lymphatic

2: Subcapsular sinus

3: Cortical sinus

4: Efferent lymphatic

5:  Medullary sinus
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of flow of lymph inside a lymph node is 1-2-3-5-4 (Afferent lymphatic → Subcapsular sinus → Cortical sinus → Medullary sinus → Efferent lymphatic).

The lymph node acts as a filter for lymph before it enters venous circulation. Understanding its internal structure helps explain the lymph flow pathway.

1. Entry through Afferent Lymphatic Vessels

* Lymph enters the lymph node through afferent lymphatic vessels, which open into the subcapsular sinus (also called the marginal sinus).

* These afferent vessels pierce the capsule but do NOT directly open into cortical or medullary sinuses.

2. Subcapsular Sinus (Marginal Sinus)

* Located just beneath the capsule.

* Receives lymph from afferent lymphatics and distributes it to the cortical (trabecular) sinuses.

3. Cortical Sinuses (Trabecular Sinuses)

* Lymph flows from the subcapsular sinus into the cortical sinuses, which extend along trabeculae into the cortex.

* This area contains lymphoid follicles (B-cell zones) and the paracortex (T-cell zone), where immune interactions occur.

4. Medullary Sinuses

* From cortical sinuses, lymph passes into the medullary sinuses located in the medulla.

* These sinuses converge near the hilum of the lymph node.

5. Exit through Efferent Lymphatic Vessel

Finally, lymph leaves the lymph node via efferent lymphatic vessels at the hilum, after being filtered and processed by immune cells.

questions.text: 32. Which of the following is not a boundary of the maxillary sinus?

choices.text: Alveolar and palatine processes of maxilla
Orbital plate of the frontal bone

questions.solution:
The orbital plate of the frontal bone is not a boundary of the maxillary sinus. 

The following are the boundaries of the maxillary sinus:

Wall Boundary
Anterior wall Facial surface of maxilla
Posterior wall Infratemporal and pterygopalatine fossae  
Medial wall Middle and inferior meatuses
Floor

Alveolar and palatine processes of maxilla
Roof

Floor of the orbit


The maxillary sinus is an air cavity in the maxilla and is part of the anterior group of paranasal sinuses. It is also known as the Antrum of Highmore. Its appearance is described as a pyramid, with its base being formed by the nasal wall and the apex pointing towards the zygomatic process. 

The mucus produced by the maxillary sinus is drained through the natural ostium into the middle meatus. 

The role of the paranasal sinuses is to humidify and warm the inspired air, to add resonance to voice, to lighten the skull bone, act as thermal insulators for the organs in the orbit, to increase olfactory sensation surface, and to provide a buffer for trauma. 

Image below shows sagittal and coronal view of maxillary sinus respectively.







Pearl PM1424: Structures opening into meatuses of nose

* Inferior meatus: Nasolacrimal duct, guarded by the valve of Hasner

* Middle meatus: Frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, anterior ethmoidal sinus. All these together form the osteo-meatal complex or Picadle’s circle.

* Superior meatus: Posterior ethmoidal sinus

* Sphenoethmoidal recess: Sphenoid sinus

questions.text: 33. A neonate with a central diaphragmatic hernia is suspected to have a defect in the development of the septum transversum. All of the following are derivatives of the defective structure, except?
questions.solution:
The gastrosplenic ligament is not a derivative of the septum transversum, but a derivative of the dorsal mesogastrium.

The septum transversum gives rise to:

* Central tendon of the diaphragm

* Connective tissue of the liver

* Ventral mesentery of the foregut. It has the following parts

* Lesser omentum (ventral mesogastrium)

* Ligaments of the liver (falciform ligament, triangular ligaments, and coronary ligaments)

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia results due to the failure of various structures forming the diaphragm to fuse. It occurs in 1/2000 births. The defect allows abdominal viscera to enter the pleural cavity. It is most frequently caused by the failure of one or both of the pleuroperitoneal membranes to fuse. The two well-recognized congenital sites where abdominal viscera can herniate into the chest are:

* The foramen of Morgagni: a hernia in the anteromedial part of the diaphragm with a defect between the sternal and costal attachments. The most commonly involved viscus is the transverse colon.

* The foramen of Bochdalek: through the dome of the diaphragm posterolaterally.



Pearl PM2134: Congenital diaphragmatic hernias (CDH)

It is due to the failure of the closure of the pleuroperitoneal canal in the developing fetus (Normally the pleuroperitoneal cavities separate by 8-10 weeks of gestation). Left-sided hernias are more common(80%).

The two well-recognized congenital sites where abdominal viscera can herniate into the chest are:

* The foramen of Morgagni: a hernia in the anteromedial part of the diaphragm with a defect between the sternal and costal attachments. The most commonly involved viscus is the transverse colon.

* The foramen of Bochdalek: through the dome of the diaphragm posterolaterally

CDH causes pulmonary hypoplasia (bilateral) by compressing the developing lung. These lungs have smaller bronchi, with less bronchial branching and less alveolar surface area than lungs in normal infants. Pulmonary hypertension may also develop due to increased thickness of arteriolar smooth muscle and also by multiple local and systemic vasoactive factors.

Clinical features:

* respiratory distress at birth

* grunting respiration

* chest retractions

* dyspnea

* cyanosis

* scaphoid abdomen

* decreased breath sounds along with bowel sound over the chest with CDH

* shifting of heart sounds to the right (for left-sided CDH)

questions.text: 34. A 55-year-old man presents with a soft, reducible swelling in the left lumbar region that increases in size on coughing and straining. On inspection the swelling is seen to arise from the lumbar triangle of Petit. Which of the following muscles forms the medial boundary of this space?
questions.solution:
The medial wall of the lumbar triangle of Petit is formed by latissimus dorsi muscle.

The lumbar triangle of Petit is a small, muscle-bound triangle.

* The medial border is formed by the lateral edge of the latissimus dorsi.

* The lateral border is formed by the posterior edge of the external oblique muscle of the abdomen.

* The inferior border is formed by the iliac crest.



Lumbar hernias primarily occur through the inferior lumbar triangle of Petit. Less frequently, they may emerge through the superior lumbar triangle, which is bordered by the twelfth rib superiorly, the sacrospinalis muscle medially, and the posterior edge of the internal oblique muscle laterally. 

Surgery is recommended for lumbar hernias, as they tend to enlarge naturally. Both open and laparoscopic surgical approaches are viable. For smaller hernias, the trans-abdominal preperitoneal (TAPP) laparoscopic approach is increasingly favored.

* 12th rib

* Paraspinal muscles

* Internal oblique muscle.

Inferior lumbar triangle (Petit triangle) - Bounded by the

* Iliac crest

* Latissimus dorsi muscle

* External oblique muscle. 

Dowd’s operation is done for lumbar hernia

questions.text: 35. The marked triangle is bound by all of the following except ___________.
questions.solution:
The marked area represents triangle of Koch. The AV node does not form a boundary of this triangle.

The triangle of Koch is found on the smooth posterior wall of the right atrium. It contains the atrioventricular node. It is bound by:

* Coronary sinus

* Tendon of Todaro

* Septal cusp of the tricuspid valve

The triangle is an important surgical landmark for identifying the location of the AV node during cardiac surgeries. The AV node lies near the apex of this triangle, which can be seen in the image below bound by the dashed blue lines:

questions.text: 36. Example of traction epiphysis is:
questions.solution:
Tibial tuberosity is type of traction epiphysis.

Traction epiphysis is the region of the long bone that is non-articular, i.e., not involved in joint formation. Unlike pressure epiphyses, these regions do not assist in weight transmission.



Pearl PM0703: Types of Epiphysis

There are four types of epiphysis.

Pressure epiphysis

* Articular and assist in the transmission of weight

* Found in regions of the bone that are under pressure during movement or locomotion

* Examples: Head of the humerus, Head of the femur, Condyles of femur and tibia

Traction epiphysis

* Non-articular and do not transmit weight

* Provide attachment to one or more tendons that exert traction on the epiphysis

* Traction epiphyses ossify later than pressure epiphyses

* Examples: Greater and lesser tubercles of the humerus, and greater and lesser trochanters of the femur

Atavistic epiphysis

* An independent bone in lower animals but in humans has fused to another bone

* Examples: Coracoid process is fused to the scapula in humans but is a separate bone in four-legged animals

Aberrant epiphysis

* Deviations from the normal and are not always present

* Example: Epiphysis at the head of the first metacarpal and at the base of the other metacarpal bones

questions.text: 37. A 40-year-old man presents with numbness and paresthesia over the area marked with X in the image. Through which foramen does the nerve associated with this condition pass?
questions.solution:
The area marked in the image is supplied by the maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve. It passes through the foramen rotundum.

The Foramen rotundum is situated on the floor of the middle cranial fossa, posterior to the medial end of the superior orbital fissure. It serves as a passageway for the maxillary nerve (V2) as it travels from the middle cranial fossa to the pterygopalatine fossa.

The maxillary nerve is responsible for sensation over the mid-face, lower eyelid, nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses, upper lip, maxillary teeth, and palate.

 

The area marked as yellow is supplied by the ophthalmic division (V1) of the trigeminal nerve. It enters the orbit through superior orbital fissure.

The area marked as blue is supplied by the mandibular division (V3) of the trigeminal nerve. It passes through foramen ovale.

questions.text: 38. Sphenopalatine foramen transmits all of the following structures, except ______.
questions.solution:
Sphenopalatine foramen does not transmit anterior ethmoidal nerve.

The anterior ethmoidal nerve is a branch of the ciliary ganglion. It enters the cranial cavity through the anterior ethmoidal foramen and canal. There it runs forwards in a groove on the upper surface of the cribriform plate beneath the dura mater, and through a slit lateral to the crista galli, descends into the nasal cavity where it gives off the medial and lateral internal nasal branches.

The sphenopalatine foramen serves as a gateway between the pterygopalatine fossa and the nasal cavity. It transmits the following structures from the pterygopalatine fossa to the nasal cavity:

* Sphenopalatine artery

* Nasopalatine nerve

* Posterior superior nasal nerves (lateral and medial)

questions.text: 39. The furcal nerve which connects the lumbar and sacral plexus together most commonly arises from which of the following nerve roots?
questions.solution:
The furcal nerve (nervi furcalis) most commonly arises from the L4 root.

The furcal nerve, an anomalous, independent nerve root with its own dorsal root ganglion and rootlets most commonly originates from the L4 (fourth lumbar) level. Its branches contribute to the femoral and obturator.

The furcal nerve links the lumbar and sacral plexuses, evidenced by its forked structure. Its branches extend to the femoral and obturator nerves, both originating from the lumbar plexus, and to the lumbosacral trunk. Occasionally, the furcal nerve may emerge at the level of the third or fifth lumbar spinal nerves, leading to the sacral plexus being classified as prefixed or postfixed, respectively.

Pearl PM1236: Lumbar Plexus

Lumbar plexus is formed by the divisions of the first four lumbar nerves (L1-L4) and from contributions of the subcostal nerve (T12), which is the last thoracic nerve.

questions.text: 40. A 45-year-old painter presented with chronic right shoulder pain. On examination, the patient can only initiate abduction up to 15° and not beyond. The muscle injured in this case belongs to which of the following categories?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, the deltoid muscle (multipennate) is injured as abduction beyond 15° is carried out by this muscle. 

Muscles with oblique fibers are subclassified as follows:

* Triangular: They are triangular in shape. E.g., temporalis, adductor longus, trapezius

* Pennate: They are feather-shaped. Based on their complexity, they can have the following subtypes:

* Unipennate: Fascicles on one side of the tendon. E.g., flexor pollicis longus, extensor digitorum longus, peroneus tertius, and, palmar interossei

* Bipennate: Fascicles on two sides of the tendon. E.g., rectus femoris, peroneus longus, flexor hallucis longus, and dorsal interossei

* Multipennate: Central tendon branches into two or more branches within the muscle. E.g., deltoid, subscapularis

* Circumpennate (radial): Muscle fibers converge to a central tendon in a radial fashion. E.g., tibialis anterior



Muscles involved in the abduction of the shoulder:

* The first 15° of abduction is initiated by the supraspinatus muscle (Both deltoid and supraspinatus help in initiation).

* The next 15° to 90° of abduction is carried out mainly by the middle fibres of the deltoid muscle.

* Abduction of the arm beyond 90° is carried out by the movement of the shoulder girdle caused by the action of the trapezius and serratus anterior,

Pearl PM1973: Classification of muscles according to their shape/direction of muscle fibers

Muscles with parallel fasciculi

Muscles with oblique fasciculi

Muscles with spiral or twisted fasciculi

Triangular: Temporalis, Adductor longus, 

Spiral: Pectoralis major, Latissimus dorsi, Supinator and Trapezius

Strap like: Sartorius, Sternohyoid

Unipennate: Extensor digitorum longus, Flexor pollicis longus, Peroneus tertius, Palmar interossei

Partially cruciate and partially spiral: Masseter, Adductor magnus, Sternocleidomastoid 

Strap like with tendinous intersections: Rectus abdominis

Bipennate: Rectus femoris, Flexor hallucis longus, Peroneus longus, Dorsal interossei

 

Fusiform: Biceps brachii, digastric

Multipennate: Deltoid, Subscapularis

  

 

Circumpennate: Tibialis anterior

questions.text: 41. The suprapleural membrane which covers the apex of the lungs is an extension of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Suprapleural membrane or Sibson’s fascia is an extension of endothoracic fascia and scalenus minimus.

Sibson's fascia (suprapleural membrane) serves as a plane of separation between the lower neck and the thorax and covers the apical part of the lung. It is attached to the inner border of the 1st rib and posteriorly to the anterior border of the transverse process of the C7 vertebra. It is strengthened by a few spreading muscular fibers derived from the scalene muscles. The subclavian vessels lie on top of it.

Clinical Significance

* Prevents upward protrusion of pleura and lung into the neck during inspiration.

* Site of spread of infections or tumors from the neck to thoracic cavity (and vice versa).

* Possible injury during subclavian vein catheterization, leading to pneumothorax.

* In pancoast tumors (apical lung tumors), it can be involved, causing brachial plexus compression.



Other Options- 

Option A- Prevertebral Fascia: Covers the vertebral column and associated muscles (longus colli, scalenes). Extends from skull base to T3, enclosing the brachial plexus and subclavian vessels. Forms the floor of the posterior triangle.

Option C- Clavipectoral Fascia: Located in the axilla, deep to pectoralis major. Encloses subclavius and pectoralis minor. Pierced by cephalic vein, thoracoacromial artery, and lateral pectoral nerve. Protects axillary vessels.

Option D- Alar Fascia: A thin layer of fascia between the prevertebral fascia and buccopharyngeal fascia. Creates the retropharyngeal space, allowing spread of infections from pharynx to mediastinum.

questions.text: 42. A female patient presented with midline neck swelling to the outpatient department. While examining the thyroid gland, you observe that the swelling does not extend superiorly. Which of the following structures is responsible for this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
The upward extension of the thyroid swelling is prevented by the attachment of the sternothyroid to the thyroid cartilage.

The thyroid gland can only enlarge anteriorly, posteriorly, laterally, and inferiorly. The superior extension of thyroid swelling is limited by two muscles namely: sternothyroid and sternohyoid.

Other options:

Option A: Thyrohyoid membrane is a fibro-elastic ligament, which arises from the superior margin of the thyroid cartilage, and gets attached to the hyoid bone. It facilitates the upward movement of the larynx during swallowing.

Option C: Pretrachial fascia encloses the thyroid gland and is attached to the larynx. This attachment is responsible for the movement of the enlarged thyroid gland on deglutition.

Option D: The ligament of berry, also called suspensory ligament extends from the cricoid cartilage to the thyroid. Its attachment prevents the thyroid gland from sinking down into the mediastinum.

questions.text:
43. A patient undergoes VATS for right upper lobectomy for a lung tumor. Which of the following fissures does the surgeon need to identify to delimit the boundary between the upper and middle lobes of the right lung?

VATS- Video-Assisted Thoracoscopic Surgery
questions.solution:
Horizontal fissure separates the right upper lobe from the right middle lobe..

Right lung has 3 lobes:

* Upper lobe → apical, anterior, posterior segments

* Middle lobe → medial, lateral segments

* Lower lobe → superior, basal segments

Right lung has 2 fissures:

* Horizontal fissure (minor fissure): Separates upper lobe from middle lobe.

* Oblique fissure (major fissure): Separates lower lobe from upper & middle lobes

Video-Assisted Thoracoscopic Surgery (VATS): A minimally invasive thoracic surgical technique where operations inside the chest are performed using a thoracoscope and specialized instruments through small incisions, instead of an open thoracotomy.

Other options-

Option B- Oblique fissure → separates lower lobe from both upper & middle lobes. 

Option C- Accessory fissure → anatomical variations that sometimes divide segments abnormally (e.g., superior accessory fissure, inferior accessory fissure).

Option D- Incomplete fissure → refers to a developmental anomaly where a fissure doesn’t completely separate lobes.

questions.text: 44. Which of the following best describes the primary movement responsible for locking of the knee during the last phase of extension?

choices.text: Medial rotation of the tibia on femur
Lateral rotation of the femur on tibia
Medial rotation of the femur on tibia
Lateral rotation of the tibia on femur

questions.solution:
The primary movement responsible for locking of the knee during the last phase of extension is medial rotation of the femur on tibia.

Locking of the knee is the medial rotation of the femur on the tibia during the later stages of extension. When standing, the knee joint is locked into position to reduce the amount of muscle work needed to maintain the standing position. The muscle responsible for locking is vastus medialis. 

The image given below shows the locking of the knee joint while standing.



Unlocking of the knee joint is the lateral rotation of the femur on the tibia during the beginning of flexion. This is brought by the action of the popliteus muscle.

questions.text: 45. A 58-year-old man presents with progressive difficulty in voluntary movement on the right side of his body. On examination there is increased tone in the muscles of right upper and lower limbs. Babinski sign is positive on the right side. MRI reveals a lesion in the left precentral gyrus of the frontal lobe. Which of the following cortical layers contains the cells giving rise to the tracts affected in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of the involvement of inner pyramidal layer.

Right-sided weakness with spasticity, hypertonia, and Babinski sign indicates an upper motor neuron lesion. Lesion in the left precentral gyrus (primary motor cortex) localizes to the corticospinal tract origin. Thus, the affected cortical layer is inner pyramidal layer, containing Betz cells, which gives rise to corticospinal fibers.

The layers of the cerebral cortex are shown in the diagram below.



The course of corticospinal tract is shown below:



Pearl PM2248: Layers of Cerebral Cortex

Layers of Cerebral Cortex

Molecular layer (I)

  • the superficial layer deep to the pia mater.

External granular layer (II)

External pyramidal layer (III)

  • gives rise to association and commissural fibers.

Internal granular layer (IV)

  • receives thalamocortical fibers from the thalamic nuclei of the ventral tier (e.g., ventral posterolateral [VPL] and ventral posteromedial [VPM] nuclei).
  • in the striate cortex (area 17), receives input from the lateral geniculate body
  • myelinated fibers of this layer form the stripe of Gennari—visible to the naked eye

Internal pyramidal layer (V)

  • gives rise to corticobulbar, corticospinal, and corticostriatal fibers
  • contains the giant cells of Betz that are found only in the motor cortex (area 4) of the precentral gyrus and the anterior paracentral lobule

Multiform layer (VI)

  • the deepest layer of the cortex. It gives rise to projection, commissural, and association fibers.
  • the major source of corticothalamic fibers.

Note: Cerebrum has 2 types of layer arrangements, neocortex has 6 layers and allocortex has 3 layers.

questions.text: 46. Which among the following marked cells are considered as members of amine precursor uptake and decarboxylation (APUD) system of dispersed neuroendocrine cells?
questions.solution:
The cells marked 'B' are the parafollicular cells/C-cells which are considered as members of amine precursor uptake and decarboxylation (APUD) system of dispersed neuroendocrine cells.

The C-cells (clear cells or parafollicular cells) have a pale staining cytoplasm, they are present between the follicular cells and the basement membrane or between the follicles. They are usually found in the middle third of each lateral lobe of the thyroid and scattered in between the thyroid follicles. They are members of the APUD system of dispersed neuroendocrine cells. They secrete calcitonin which lowers blood calcium.

The thyroid gland is covered by a fibrous capsule with septae dividing it into lobules. These lobules contain follicles lined by follicular cells. The shape of the follicular cells depends on the activity of the gland. They're squamous in the inactive state, cuboidal to columnar in the active state. The cavity of the follicle contains colloid which appears pink in H and E staining.

questions.text:
48. A 60-year-old male patient who has a known history of diabetes mellitus and hypertension was diagnosed with Wallenberg syndrome. He developed dysphagia, dysarthria, and hoarseness of voice. What is the cranial nerve nucleus involved and the functional column it belongs to?

NTS: Nucleus of Tractus Solitarius

choices.text: Nucleus ambiguus, general visceral efferent column
Nucleus ambiguus, special visceral efferent column

questions.solution:
Dysphagia, dysarthria, and hoarseness of voice seen in Wallenberg syndrome is due to the involvement of the nucleus ambiguus from the special visceral efferent column.

Nucleus ambiguus is a common motor nucleus containing the efferent fibers of the glossopharyngeal (CN IX) and the vagus (CN X) nerves. These supply the pharyngeal constrictors, intrinsic laryngeal muscles, and striated muscles of the palate and upper esophagus. This nucleus is also involved in the gag reflex and the cardiac parasympathetic activity. Nucleus ambiguus arises from the special visceral efferent column present in the medulla.

Lesions this nucleus in leads to dysphagia, dysarthria, and hoarseness of voice seen in Wallenberg syndrome. Wallenberg syndrome occurs due to thrombosis in the vertebral artery or posterior inferior cerebellar artery (the most tortuous artery in the body) causing infarction of the inferior cerebellar peduncle, nucleus ambiguus, vestibular nucleus, spinal lemniscus, the spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve, and the sympathetic chain. 

This results in ipsilateral ataxia, loss of pain and temperature, drooping of the eyelid, miosis, anhidrosis, loss of ciliospinal reflex, apparent enophthalmos, dysphagia, dysarthria, nasal regurgitation, hoarseness of voice, contralateral loss of pain and temperature, vertigo, nystagmus, and vomiting.

Nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) (Options B and D) arises from the special visceral afferent and the general visceral afferent columns.

questions.text: 49. A road traffic accident patient with an injury to the neck was brought to the emergency department. She had decreased sensations over the deltoid and lateral aspect of arm. The nerve root injured in this patient is _________.
questions.solution:

C2 injury leads to decreased sensation over the back of the scalp. C3 injury leads to decreased sensation over the anterior aspect of the neck. C4 injury leads to decreased sensation over the lateral aspect of the neck and inferiorly over clavicles down to the rib space

questions.text: 50. Which of the following is a circumventricular organ that has tanycytes and lacks a blood-brain barrier?
questions.solution:
Organum vasculosum is a circumventricular organ that has tanycytes and lacks a blood-brain barrier.

Blood-brain barriers are the barriers present in the capillary endothelium of the brain. Structures forming the blood-brain barrier are the tight junctions between the endothelial cells and the feet end of astrocytes.

Circumventricular organs are midline structures in the ventricular wall that lack a normal blood-brain barrier (BBB). These are lined by specialized ependymal cells called tanycytes.



Other options:

Options B and C: Suprafornical and supracommissural organs are false options, the other circumventricular organs are subfornical and subcommissural organs.

Option D: Anterior pituitary is a false option, posterior pituitary is a circumventricular organ.

Pearl PM0062: Circumventricular Organs (CVO)

The following are the circumventricular organs (CVO) or areas devoid of the blood-brain barrier:

* Pineal body

* Neurohypophysis

* Organum Vasculosum of Lamina Terminalis (OVLT)

* Median Eminence (hypothalamus)

* Subcommissural organ

* Subfornical organ

* Area Postrema

  • Protoplasmic – in grey matter

They take up glutamate and convert into  glutamine
